review.reviewBody: I've been wanting a new pair of overalls for quite sometime. After shopping around I landed on these, and I'm so glad I did. I love the brown/tan color and how all the seems look. There's stretch to the shoulder straps and many useful pockets. I also love how small the brand logo is, so it doesn't distract from the overall appearance. I'm 5'8" and 152lbs. I typically wear a size 6 or S/M. I went with the medium, and they're just roomy enough without being too baggy. I look forward to being able to wear sweaters under them in the colder weather.
review.name: Comfortable and attractive

name: Trailworks Overall - Women's

description: Buy the Thule Accent 20L Backpack online or shop all Accessories from Backcountry.com.

hasVariant.name: Accent 20L Backpack
hasVariant.description: Buy the Thule Accent 20L Backpack online or shop all Accessories from Backcountry.com.

review.reviewBody: I'm 5.2' and was looking for something with back support. I commute everyday and was sold on this bag for its size (45cm long great for a shorter person like myself) and the compartment for sunglasses which holds more than sunglasses. I can't fit my lunchbox but I don't have to take it off in the subway because of its size. It might be small for travelling but perfect for work.
review.name: Compact for daily commute

review.reviewBody:
I bought this because i wanted to carry my Apple 16inch laptop and DLSR camera in a bag that i can pass as a personal item...AND i can still bring a carry-on roller on the plane. (this bag can also attach to the handles of the carry on so i dont even have to carry it around in my back.  My previous bag was the bigger 40L and it prevented me to bring an additional carry on, AND i had to carry all that weight in my back the entire time i was waiting to board. (sometimes that could be hours on a layover.)  So this bag solved that problem.
It is just slightly bigger than the United measurements, but only by fractions...its not a hardshell or rigid, so i feel it will fit inside the box.
Some things i wish it had....1) keychain lanyard inside. 2) a way to attach a lock on the top and back zipper pouches to guard against pickpocket when you travel. 3) Molle or loops on the front straps so you can attach additional pouches to hold your wallet or passport or phone.
Overall, this is a great bag that is the right measurements for my purpose.
review.name: Perfect size for personal item in plane...

review.reviewBody: Thule always makes quality items; no issue there. I love that this backpack is small and lightweight and meets my daily needs as a professor. It fits my 15” MacBook Air, a thin file folder, computer charger, dry erase markers, other writing utensils, and a water bottle. There isn’t room for much else. The zipper to the main compartment is shorter than I was expecting, which makes the backpack a little rigid and difficult to fill to capacity. Not a dealbreaker for me, and I’m happy with my purchase! An advantage of the short zipper is that the backpack feels very sturdy.
review.name: Great quality, less storage than expected

review.reviewBody: It is the perfect size to carry to work and school as a backpack and compact to attach to your carry-on luggage for travel. Highly recommended if you don't like to check-in bags at the airport.
review.name: Excellent for School, Work and Travel

review.reviewBody: This backpack is the perfect size for my commute! It’s high quality and stylish! The only issue…I love it so much, that now I want a larger one for travel.
review.name: Great compact backpack

review.reviewBody: it's well made, very lightweight, and carries very light on the shoulder.  I would recommend it to anyone that carries a laptop or iPad and a few chargers.
review.name: excelent backpack

review.reviewBody: Just bought this pack. My 15,6" laptop easy fits in. Main complaint about this backpack - there are no hook for keys! That's why only 4 stars.
review.name: Good everyday pack

name: Accent 20L Backpack

review.reviewBody: Set it and forget it. This PFD is comfortable first and foremost, but most importantly for me, it stays in place. I actually bought this for sailing on the Chesapeake Bay. I'm scrambling all over the boat, and the last thing I want is to have to keep readjusting my life jacket. This thing snugs down, is incredibly comfortable, gives me full range of motion in any direction, and it stays put. The icing on the cake is the stowable strap ends. Not having those things flapping about in my face is awesome.
review.name: Built for Speed

review.reviewBody: As a stand up paddler, it is a challenge to climb back on the board after you have fallen in. But, where I live the water is cold most of the year and I just do not feel comfortable only wearing the SUP waist pack inflatable. The Ion solved my problem and is the best one I have found, easy to swim in, climb back on with and great range of motion.
review.name: Thinnest PFD I have worn.

name: Ion Personal Flotation Device

review.itemreviewed: Merino 125 ZoneKnit Energy Wind Long-Sleeve T-Shirt- Women's
review.reviewBody: This shirt runs short and wide. I think it will fit great if you are under 5'6 and curvy. I returned both the medium and large. I usually wear a large in icebreaker running tops. They did not give me a refund for the returned tops and it was not the first time this has happened to me. The customer service is poor and you have to work hard to get your refund. I'm very disappointed.
review.name: Short and wide fit

review.itemreviewed: Merino 125 ZoneKnit Energy Wind Long-Sleeve T-Shirt- Women's
review.reviewBody: This top is perfect for those spring runs where you want a little coverage or in summer when you want a little protection. The 125 weight is lightweight and the perforated knit back and sides lets some of the heat out. It is slightly cropped. I'm 5'3 and the small fits nicely.
review.name: Perfect for spring/summer runs

name: Merino 125 ZoneKnit Energy Wind Long-Sleeve T-Shirt- Women's

review.reviewBody: I learned after ordering these that Giro is notorious for low volume cycling shoes. Some people like that "one with the pedal" feel but I found it too restricting on top of my toes. I switched to the Giro Ventana (also 45) which uses a different shoe last more like their normal shoes and the fit was much better. Maybe just ordering up 2 sizes or so would have been enough but I love the Ventana!
review.name: Low volume

review.reviewBody:
These are comparable to Continental X-Kings with respect to weight, purpose and knob placement and spacing.

I initially ran these up front paired with a Mezcal III in back but immediately found myself missing the predictability of my previous front, a Continental Hans Dampf. So I moved the Barzo to the rear on a different bike and found it to be a fast, reliable roller. 

Despite the product sheet stating that Graphene 2.0 offers improved wet weather grip, Barzos are best suited for dry conditions. Those wanting to ride in the slop would do well to consider Motas or Mazzas, instead.
review.name: Better Rear than Front Tire

review.reviewBody: I love these tires, I tried them back to back with the Bontrager XR2s and the Barzos are hands down better.. They feel much more planted and stable.
review.name: Vittoria Barzos

name: Barzo G2.0 4C XC Trail 27.5in Tire

description: Buy the Garmin Edge 1040 GPS Bike Computer online or shop all Bike from Backcountry.com.

hasVariant.name: Edge 1040 GPS Bike Computer
hasVariant.description: Buy the Garmin Edge 1040 GPS Bike Computer online or shop all Bike from Backcountry.com.

review.reviewBody: I very happy with my new Garmin every thing is super
review.name: Excellent

review.reviewBody: Coming from the Garmin wrist watches the instability and unpredictability of the 1040's software has been aggravating. It has barely gotten better over successive software releases. Check out the user forums for examples from other users. The most recent issue I personally had was that updates to maps with the device only pretty much never succeed because the device turns off before the 10+ hour download completes. And the Garmin Express Mac app always aborted with an "unknown error" until I factory reset the Edge.
review.name: Incredibly buggy software

review.reviewBody: I bought this a few weeks ago to go along with the Varia RCT715 that I bought at the same time.  The unit works well but I really couldn't hear the sound chime when a car showed up in the radar screen and sadly the 1040 doesn't have volume control like the 1050 so I'm a very safety conscious rider and right now I have buyers remorse because the 1040 doesn't have this feature which makes the Varia RCT715 not as functional as I was hoping.  So buyers beware!!!!
review.name: more basic features needed to make it functional

review.reviewBody: I upgraded to the 1040 from my *old* 705....yes, you read that right 705....   What a great device. Garmin has always delivered and exceeded my expectations, but I have to say that  with the 1040 I'm blown away.  The ease of use, feature menu, functionality and intuitive nature make the 1040 a great choice for me.  Looking forward to getting many years of service from the new 1040.
review.name: What an amazing bike computer!

review.reviewBody: Only way to see the absurdly dim display is to ride in the dark.
review.name: Garmin 1040 in the dark

review.reviewBody: Have had this about a month and find it is easy to use. I was having trouble reading my other Garmin and this one works great for me. The maps are easy to follow and see. Everything else that i have tried also works very well. Would definitely recommend this to anyone who is thinking about a bike computer.
review.name: Works Great and easy to use

review.reviewBody: Easy to use and navigate I like the color screens.
review.name: Syncs with GPS and sensors fast!

review.reviewBody: I purchased a new Garmin 1040 when my 1030 finally fell apart after many years of rough roads and use! The new device has many new features which are more user friendly and useful! The navigation has a feature to return to start location via reverse route or most direct! Love it!! The screen display is in color and very easy to read, day or night! The battery life is as good or better than my 1030, which gives me all day riding capacity without worry for power.
review.name: Great got Better

review.reviewBody: The larger screen accommodates great viewing even with 10 data fields.   The flexibility to change and modify on the fly is great.
review.name: Excellent device

review.reviewBody: I bought the Garmin 1040 computer to work with my power meter pedals. It is the first and only computer of this type that I’ve purchased so my ability to compare it to others is not possible.  However, being a 70 year old cyclist who’s ridden and done some racing over my 50 years on a bike I can say that it has exceeded my expectations.  I’m somewhat computer literate, not an expert by any means but,  the unit is easy to use, tracks all the training or race data that my coach and I will ever need and the battery runs a very long time between charges.  So am I pleased with the thing? Yes indeed.
review.name: Smarter than me!

name: Edge 1040 GPS Bike Computer

review.reviewBody: XL used to fit me perfectly but no longer. These are just too big. And the jasper is so horrendous in real life that three girls actually beat me up for offending their sense of decency. They are really ugly and match nothing. Sometimes the sale price isn't worth it, even to get the best chamois in the world.
review.name: Not Your Last Season's Pearl Izumi

review.reviewBody: As others have mentioned, these are snug, but they are cycling bibs, eh? I think they are sized as advertised, or maybe a bit small if you're in between sizes. I like how the edges of the fabric on the legs and on the upper section are unhemmed. They feel invisible. Also, the pad, which is a little thicker than I normally buy (I find that thick pads can cause saddle sores) are dense and extremely comfortable.
review.name: I love the unhemmed edges

review.reviewBody: Initial fit feels tight, but feels perfect during riding. It’s the only bib short I wear now.  Will definitely buy again.
review.name: Highly recommend

review.reviewBody: Wore two pairs of these bibs about 400km over three warm days in Mallorca. The fabric is nice and soft, the padding also greenish and comfy.  Bottom line was no chafe, and no pains. I’ve just ordered two more pairs in case they are crazy enough to try to improve on perfection.
review.name: Most comfortable bibs I’ve ever owned

review.reviewBody: Of course gear choice is subjective to each user, but I agree with other comments here. These are by far the most comfortable, best fit/fabric, and functional bib shorts I’ve ever worn. Currently own three pair, purchasing pairs two and three on Competitive Cyclist sales in large part to make sure I have stock should PI ever change the design.
review.name: Pearl Izumi Pro Bib Shorts

review.reviewBody: I have tried many different brands of bib shorts, including Rapha, ASOS, Pactimo, and others. All of these have good features but none of them have it all the way these shorts do. They’re comfortable. The chamois is the best of anything I’ve tried. The straps are barely there.   They just make you want to go for a ride. For me, these are the standard by which all other bib shorts are judged. So far no others compare.
review.name: Gold standard bib shorts

review.reviewBody: For most of my rides I don't run a full bib short, usually either just a liner under baggies or a half short, but when I do decide to go on a longer ride and plan to spend several hours in the saddle, a pair of proper bibs are essential. The Pearl Izumi pro bibs are light enough to forget they exist, compressive enough to reduce fatigue but stretch enough to not cause discomfort 6 hours into the day. The Levitate Pro chamois is easily my favorite for the long hauls and the unique colorways are appreciated.
review.name: My Go-to bib short

name: Pro Bib Short - Men's

review.itemreviewed: Terreno Mix G2.0 TNT Tubeless Tire
review.reviewBody: The tire is OK, typical Vittoria?s product. My complain is the size; it was virtually impossible to put it on a standard Fulcrum rim with two hands (never happened to me). I had to ask a friend?s help, and it took 15 min of massaging and stretching it + a gallon of sweat to figure out how to pull it on the rim. I do understand why they do that: once it is on the rim, it is really easy to pump it tubeless even with regular pump, and it will hold the air very well. But it could be a real problem, if you will have to deal with this tire alone in the middle of nowhere.
review.name: Unforgivably small

name: Terreno Mix G2.0 TNT Tubeless Tire

description: Buy the NEMO Equipment Inc. Astro Sleeping Pad online or shop all Hike & Camp from Backcountry.com.

hasVariant.name: Astro Sleeping Pad
hasVariant.description: Buy the NEMO Equipment Inc. Astro Sleeping Pad online or shop all Hike & Camp from Backcountry.com.

review.reviewBody: I got this at Thanksgiving so haven't used it yet.  But it's light enough and not to hard to put in the stuff sack.  I think I will be nice as I am getting older at 66.
review.name: Seems like a good pad

review.reviewBody: Very pleased with this pad. I've had both hips replaced and I'm a side sleeper - no issues or pain as opposed to my older Thermarest.  Recently returned from a 3 day - 2 hike in the Black Mountains of NC and temps the first night were in the low 20's. I was concerned about the R-value in those temps, but we prepped the ground under the tent with pine needles, and if didn't experience cold transfer issues from the ground. There are two reasons I didn't rate the Astro with 5-stars. 1. When removing the Vortex pump sack, it was sketchy to not pull the value all the way out causing rapid deflation.  2. The tri-fold roll-up design was difficult to line up properly on a consistent basis. Both of these things are small issues in my opinion, but worthy to drop one star rating.
review.name: Great pad

review.reviewBody: Really nice and easy to inflate. Comfortable. Not loud
review.name: Hits the spot the rock or twig spot

name: Astro Sleeping Pad

review.reviewBody: It's so warm!  A walk's fine at 32, but a run at 30 is hot and sweat. With a base layer, sub-zero's degrees will no problem. I usually wear a small, and it fits perfectly, but these pants are a little big.
review.name: Warm

review.reviewBody: The knee areas seem to have very little or no insulation. Felt the wind as soon as I stepped outside. My other pair of these are great. Insulation is fine. Feel no wind when wearing.
review.name: Bad insulation

review.reviewBody: comfy, warm & fit perfectly.
review.name: STOIC PUFFER PANTS .... stoic !!!

review.reviewBody: I bought these to replace my sweatpants for early morning/late night walks with the dog... The pants are great, too warm for me to wear in the house, but wind resistant. A bit too casual to wear for anything but dog walking and grocery trips, but not an issue for my intended purpose.
review.name: Warm and wind resistant

review.reviewBody:
These pants are awesome for cold weather. First couple times I wore them my legs were sweating in <20F winter nights.

I decided to wear them skiing on a dry day, and they completely changed the way I look at snow pants.

It should be noted that they are not really water proof, however, the light material and elastic waist won me over. 

Ordered the last pair I could find in Large as a backup.

These will be my new casual ski day pants. Great deal!
review.name: Warmest Joggers Ever

review.reviewBody:
I bought these not quite knowing what to expect, but they have become my go-to early morning dog hike bottoms. These puffers feel lightweight and soft, yet cozy despite the synthetic fabric. It's been like 10F in Utah in the morning and they keep you perfectly warm, no base layer needed.

Also, the fit is perfect. I am 5'7", 145 pounds, runner's build, and these (unlike a lot of trousers labeled 'small') are the perfect length and don't make my butt look big, despite the puffer style.
review.name: Love these joggers!

name: Puffer Jogger - Men's

review.reviewBody:
Perfect softshell! I have been using it for daily commute, rock climbing and everything in between. It breaths nicely and cuts the wind just enough to protect you from the element. The fabric is nice and stretchy. 

With a base layer or insulated jacket under it, it is really versatile. Everybody can benefit from that product. 

Jacket is true to size
review.name: Fantastic for what it is

review.reviewBody: This was advertised as a soft shell jacket. When it arrived I was at first disappointed and it was very thin jacket and not like a typical soft shell jacket. Afterwards I wore it as a base layer and I learned to love it. Its similar in thickness to a merino base layer.
review.name: Not what I expected but learned to love it

review.reviewBody: Old Ferrosi is one of my all time favorite jackets (from like 2017 or thereabouts). This iteration is bad. I can just echo the other negative reviews in that it isn't as durable as my old model (still kicking after heavy use for 7 odd years), and while I initially like the idea of the dura print, they could have made it just as effective while there is infinite room for aesthetic improvement. Also my one grip from the old jacket, which they still haven't addressed, is the complete lack of structure in the hood/brim. If I'm not wearing a ball cap or sunglasses, the sides of the hood droop down next to my eyes for a poor user experience. Stop trying to appease shareholders and just make good gear.
review.name: Poor

review.reviewBody: It fits nicely, is sleek and comfortable. I can move around easily, and as an outer layer it offers exactly what I need.
review.name: Nice design, perfect outer layer.

review.reviewBody:
Full disclosure, I am a hoarding gear addict.  The garage sale when I die should be invitation only.  I am in constant search of the next best tent, sleeping bag, fleece, puffer, and/or shell.  I’ve probably purchased 25-30 Goretex or Event waterproof/breathable shells since the early 1980s.  If you add drysuits, splash tops and motorcycle gear we might be pushing 50 garments.  

So when I saw the Ferrosi hoodie at the OR outlet store, I thought “what’s this?”.  Worst of all worlds.  Not really waterproof, not really windproof, not really breathable and not really warm.  Why buy it?  But… I tried it on.  It seemed to fit well, I liked the stretch and the color was nice.  CANT STOP BUYING GEAR.  Resistance is futile…. So why not?  The poor thing needed a home. 

Wow!  After 3 months of varied use, this is my new go-to, and the logic of my initial impressions are completely reversed.  First of all, over any type of mid layer, the jacket seems weightless. Not because it’s super light, but because there is no noise or tension in any direction. The fabric just molds to you and flexes without restriction. It doesn’t seem to matter if you put it over a t-shirt, a flannel, a fleece or a down sweater, it just adapts.  Somehow it manages to both cut the wind enough and breathe quite well.  On my typical walk through the state park, a Goretex shell will be wet from condensed sweat vapor running down my back (Right?  You know what I’m talking about.. I’m convinced that Goretex is waterproof OR breathable.  Not AND. ).  The Ferrosi comes home dry.  Walking windy Pacific beaches, it stops most wind intrusion and adds probably 10 degrees of warmth.  Sitting statically at a kids soccer game in blustery 40 degree drizzle, it perfectly augments a down puffy and keeps it dry.  

It is not a raincoat, and it will probably wet-out pretty quickly in a real downpour.  But the DWR seems so effective and it beads so well, I have not had any wetting come through in my 5-6 wearings in light to moderate PNW rain and drizzle.  I get wet with Goretex from the inside out with almost any level of activity.  I’m still waiting to get wet in the Ferrosi from either direction.  But it’s not (remember) a raincoat. The fabric doesn’t have an inner coating and maybe that is why the jacket is so comfortable and versatile!.  

Are there any downsides?  Not many.  The fabric doesn’t have much body, so anything heavy in the pockets (like a phone in the chest pocket) will droop.  It’s reasonably light and rolls up pretty small, but because it is not a real rain layer, it’s an extra thing if you assume a real rain layer is mandatory in your kit for the trip.  The cuffs are a little loose and have no adjustability, so they might flop around your hands if you don’t push up the sleeves a little.  All of these are minor points.

For me the Ferrosi is a game changer that disrupts decades of being preached at with the base, mid, wpb-shell mantra.  It is possible to be dry and comfortable again in the cool and/or damp conditions I encounter 95% of the time!  

Everyone should have a Ferrosi.  Kudos OR!
review.name: Everyone should have a Ferrosi

review.reviewBody: This used to be a good jacket but as the other reviews have said the recent versions of this jacket have been pretty poor. Thinner material, more piling, loose cuffs, wind resistance isn't as effective as it used to be. Plus the "duraprint" looks terrible. Also, the black colour isn't even exactly black, it's more like a dark navy blue.
Jacket is light weight and durable looks great……..
review.name: Perfect fit, great quality

review.reviewBody: The older version of the ferrosi is maybe my favorite jacket of all time. I just got this one in the mail to replace an old one, and I'm disappointed. The drawstrings at the front of the hood are gone. The elastic at the cuffs is thinner/weaker. And the "duraprint" looks awful. OR used to have something special. But they ruined it with marketing gimmicks and with what I'm assuming cost-cutting measures.
review.name: Downgrade over previous versions of the ferrosi

review.reviewBody: While the hoodie feels nice and is appropriate for variable weather, it started pilling almost immediately at the waist and chest pockets where the fabric contacted my 35L backpack chest and hip straps (basic nylon and meshed padding, respectively). That's not a "maximum minus one" durability product, OR. I have similar 2-way stretch jackets that have stood up much better than this. The hoodie also has poor odour retention even with two 150g-200g layers of merino underneath to capture sweat. Having to wash that out after ~3 wears means the DWR coating isn't worth much unless you want to spend a lot of money and time on wash-in protection (clean cycle w/ extra rinse, treat cycle w/ extra rinse, dry cycle). That's why I tagged "Not Waterproof"; you will wash it out and the hoodie will wet out.
review.name: Microplastic Factory

review.reviewBody: I've been using this for a couple months now and really like it! I've found it cuts ~75-80% of felt wind and even as a softshell shrugs occasional rain pretty well. Mine wet out after about 25 minutes in light/medium rain and when soaked wasn't transferring much water to my baselayer. Perfect when you really should've brought a Helium Rain but you didn't. While not quite breathable enough for me when running unless its real cold (I'm a warm person) it's great for everything less aerobic than that for me. The cuffs are elastic on the inside of your wrist which works well with a watch. The single hood cinch works well to keep your hood on while minimizing adjustments. Pocket linings double as vents, are big enough for a smartphone or light gloves, and are not sewn down at the top allowing you to stash your map or mail in a pinch. The Hood stow works well when you plan to use it, but I did find myself just tucking the hood inside if I was in a rush and couldn't be bothered to roll it up. The hem cinch is located on the right side and is easy to adjust one handed and has low profile hardware which is fine under a backpack belt. I'm 5'11/ 210#/ 43" chest and wear a Men's Large size tshirt and find the size large fits me perfectly with a trim fit. Key for me with fit is that in my other OR jackets like the Foray and Superstrand I've needed to size up to XL to have the hem fit over my butt. Not so with the Ferrosi- the stretchiness of the fabric and cut works perfectly for me. I normally wear an echo or vigor top underneath mine and layer any insulation over. If I wanted to put insulation under the Ferrosi I would need to size up once. The jacket is lighter, and more flattering than my other windshell from another company. Combined with the comfiness of the stretch I've found myself grabbing it when just going out running errands and it's almost always at the top of my pack heading out into the woods now.
review.name: soft and stretchy wind protection

review.reviewBody: Comfortable and well fitted not too loose or tight. It’s also great for all seasons.
review.name: My third pair of these Boots

review.reviewBody: Bought these for just everyday boots and absolutely love them. Really no break in time at all and are light on my feet. Great for doing chores around the place to going out to dinner.
review.name: Love these boots

review.reviewBody:
I wear these shoes to work every day and everywhere. 
Tough as nails and looks great even beat up. 
I never complain about foot pain anymore with these. The soles are so tough and the wear is minimal. 
The leather does wear out after a while meaning a looser fit but the hide hold up.
I'm on my 3 or 4th pair.
review.name: Amazing

review.reviewBody: Very comfortable boots, easy to slip on without bending over, right balance between casual and classy. Took about an hour to break in and they’ve felt great since.
review.name: Great boots.

review.reviewBody: I like these boots.  They are comfortable- I have a wide foot and a high arch; these boots have a wide toe box and a good footbed.  No walking fatigue or foot discomfort.   They are not insulated, so don’t expect a go to winter boot for long days outside, but great for slushy days and the office.  4 months in I see no quality issues, no water intrusion- granted I have not fully submersed them in water, but no problems for daily Michigan winter use.  FYI, I sized up to 11, usually a 10.5 in length, but most footwear is a touch narrow for me-
review.name: Great boots - recommended

review.reviewBody:
Seams where suede meets rubber are leaking after two months of use and are no longer waterproof. I was walking in a few inches of snow and the shoes soaked through. It wasn’t like it was a big puddle or anything, just a little snow. Sorel is unwilling to accept exchange or return after 60. Very disappointed with that considering these are strongly advertised as waterproof. I recommend choosing a brand that build higher quality boots. These look nice at first but quickly fall apart. Surprised and really disappointed. 
days which I found extremely disappointing. I cannot recommend because of this. Would have otherwise been a descent shoe
review.name: Cheap construction, not waterproof
comment: Hello HC, we want to extend our apologies concerning your experience. We pride ourselves in maintaining the highest quality standards for our customers and apologize we missed the mark here.

review.reviewBody: Not nice it was cheap and seemed like suede. I returned!
review.name: Not nice
comment: Hello Will, we want to extend our apologies concerning your experience. We pride ourselves in maintaining the highest quality standards for our customers and apologize we missed the mark here.

review.reviewBody: I got these for my husband because he loved the last pair of Sorel's I surprised him with. Well, he loves these also. They look great and are waterproof. He does require inserts but that's because of his particular sole. Other than this, they fit perfectly. Can't say enough about Sorel's for my husband. He has three pairs! All are waterproof and smart looking with whatever he wears.
review.name: Love these Sorel's!

review.reviewBody: This is my second pair of Sorel Chelsea Boots. I had high hopes for these as my first pair were fantastic and I wore them for almost three years. Unfortunately, these boots have one major flaw. The area around the heal has a very hard and sharp lip where the fabrics meet to make the heal support which I found digs into my heal. Perhaps someone with a different shaped foot will not find this to be an issue, but for me it was so uncomfortable that I can't wear the shoe. I've tried the shoes out twice with different thickness of socks hoping a little extra padding would help, but I still end up with blister-like red spots on my achilles area. Aside from that one major flaw, the boots look sharp, and seem to be made from really nice materials.
review.name: Chelsea Boot
comment: Hello Orion M, we appreciate you sharing your feedback and we're sorry Men's Carson™ Chelsea Boot didn't meet your standards. We will inform our product team of your concerns and ensure this is fixed for the future.

review.reviewBody: They feel great. I am super happy with the boots. They fit well.
review.name: Love the boots!

name: Carson Chelsea WP Boot - Men's

description: Buy the Merrell Moab 3 Mid Waterproof Hiking Boot - Wide - Men's online or shop all Footwear from Backcountry.com.

hasVariant.name: Moab 3 Mid Waterproof Hiking Boot - Wide - Men's
hasVariant.description: Buy the Merrell Moab 3 Mid Waterproof Hiking Boot - Wide - Men's online or shop all Footwear from Backcountry.com.

review.itemreviewed: Moab 3 Mid Waterproof Hiking Boot - Wide - Men's
review.reviewBody: Love these hiking boots.  Fits true to size and comfortable without break-in.  I have very wide feet and usually wear 4e when I can get it.  The wide version of Moab feels great.  Also, surprisingly, they are incredibly easy to put on - I can just about step into them without struggling or using a shoehorn.  I was not expecting this -  it is a major selling point! I have taken them on several hikes now, and I feel stable on dirt, loose stone, tree branches, up-hill, down-hill, etc. The mid height is perfect for hiking, and the weight is very reasonable.  I have some much heavier leather boots that aren't as easy to hike with.  I don't really need the waterproofing I think in most cases, so I went the middle route by getting the standard waterproofing and not the gor-tech. This works great for light water exposure and i have yet to feel any moisture get through.  I don't normally write reviews, but I have so much trouble getting boots that fit comfortably due to my foot width.  Most wide shoes are either on a last that doesn't work well with my feel or are only "slightly" wider than normal D width.  Those shoes cause me significant pain, almost from the moment I put them on.  I have no pain walking in these.  The insoles are also pretty comfortable.  Also, these were on sale when I bought them, so I feel like I got a great value.  If you have wide feet and don't like to struggle to put on your boots, just buy these!
review.name: Great fit for wide feet, No shoehorn needed!

review.itemreviewed: Moab 3 Mid Waterproof Hiking Boot - Wide - Men's
review.reviewBody: I have been wearing them for 4 years and each new version is good as the prior - they did not lower quality to maintain the price. I am 71 and only hike 6.5 miles every other day around Stone Mt, N.E. Atlanta, but they kept me from twisting my ankle numerous times. I always buy them on sale which makes them an even better deal. Thanks.
review.name: Great Boots Moab 3

review.itemreviewed: Moab 3 Mid Waterproof Hiking Boot - Wide - Men's
review.reviewBody: Comfy shoes. Was a long Hoka wearer and wanted to try something new for rugged/all terrain hiking shoes. Found a bit less comfortable to start with but after a day or two, I started liking them.
review.name: Comfy pair

review.itemreviewed: Moab 3 Mid Waterproof Hiking Boot - Wide - Men's
review.reviewBody: I've been breaking these in on dog walks and at work.  Prepping for a Mighty Five week long trip in March with my 17 year old.  Very comfortable, surprisingly light weight.
review.name: Dog Walk Approved!

review.itemreviewed: Moab 3 Mid Waterproof Hiking Boot - Wide - Men's
review.reviewBody: These boots were made for walking. It's December 3rd and we have walked 723 miles so far in 2024. We take our walking seriously and these are the boots that allow me to trek in comfort over both dirt trails and concrete pavement. As a senior retired citizen, I really appreciate how easy these boots are to put on and take off after our morning 3.4-mile walks.
review.name: Comfort, Easy On & Off, Go Anywhere Boots

review.itemreviewed: Moab 3 Mid Waterproof Hiking Boot - Wide - Men's
review.reviewBody: I have purchased several different hiking boots over the years. Salomon, Keen, Hokas and Altras. I am 5’4”, weigh 120lbs and have a shoe size of 8. I tend to size up and go with a wide for hiking purposes because I like to wear a thicker sock and my foot swells on longer hikes. The mid-rise boot provides excellent support and decent water resistance. I do not require any break in time with the Moab. They are extremely comfortable right out of the box. I do have custom orthotics that I prefer to the insole that comes with the boot, but can go with or without. The boot holds up well to abuse. I hike an average of 5 miles a day. Mostly off trail - scrambling, sand, bushwhacking and rocky terrain. I am able to handle steep descents without my toes hurting.   I have purchased both mid rise and low Moab’s as gifts for friends and family. They all agree that it is a very comfortable choice. I normally wear gaiters to keep as much debris as possible from entering the shoe.  I gave 4 stars instead of 5 because the boot does not do a very good job keeping sand from entering the boot.
review.name: Hiking boot

review.itemreviewed: Moab 3 Mid Waterproof Hiking Boot - Wide - Men's
review.reviewBody: great boot overall... after a few years, the seams on the sides of the toe eventually unglue and obviously leak... otherwise, great comfort, fit and cushion for working/hiking...

review.itemreviewed: Moab 3 Mid Waterproof Hiking Boot - Wide - Men's
review.reviewBody: I got them to wear primarily to the shooting range, where the ground is extremely rocky.  With previous shoes, my feet were killing me by the end of the day because I felt the rocks through the bottom of the shoes.  These boots flex well and were strong enough to protect my feet.  They also supported my ankles whenever I walked on the constantly uneven surfaces.
review.name: I walk above and beyond.
comment: Thanks for the great feedback Mike!

review.itemreviewed: Moab 3 Mid Waterproof Hiking Boot - Wide - Men's
review.reviewBody: I had to return them because they were defective.  The fabric on the achilles area was folded over and created a pain spot.  I went out and bought some Danners instead.  I was fine not giving this review, as it was probably an anomoly, but since you asked.
review.name: Defective pair

review.itemreviewed: Moab 3 Mid Waterproof Hiking Boot - Wide - Men's
review.reviewBody: These boots fit the bill perfectly. They are comfortable, provide good traction, and are not bulky. Wore them on a retreat in the SC mountains and they performed very well. Highly recommend!
review.name: Great boots for outdoor activities

review.reviewBody: I've been through many iterations of the Vasque Breeze, for hiking, search/rescue, and everyday wear. I'm now looking for a new pair of the 7742, but I see much to my disappointment that the outer sole is no longer Vibram. The part number is the same, but the sole isn't. I won't bet my life on anything other than Vibram, so that's the end of the Breeze for me. RIP.
review.name: Where did the vibram sole go?
comment: Thank you for your honest review. We hope you will give our brand another chance in the future.

review.reviewBody: Comfort, true to size, durability, traction, waterproof. Highly recommend.
review.name: Everything in one shoe
comment: Thank you for this great review! We hope you continue to shop with us.

review.reviewBody: Breeze III GTX were the best feeling boot you offered. Went through at least 3 pairs. Any newer model has been sub par in feel and comfort.
review.name: Bring back Breeze III GTX
comment: Hello! We appreciate you taking the time to leave feedback of your experience. Customer comments and suggestions are an important part of our business and this information is essential to improving our product and brand.  I will forward this onto the Product Design and Development teams for future consideration and review!

review.reviewBody: Great boot! I have had mine for over 5 years and have nearly 1100 Strava miles on them. Sole is holding up and even the original laces show no sign of wear. I rotate use of them with another brand which I have over 1700 miles on. No complaints!
review.name: Breeze III
comment: That's awesome! It's great to hear that your boots are holding up so well. Keep on trekking! 🚶‍♂️

review.reviewBody:
My first pair I had for 5 years of daily walking around before there were just too far gone. The second pair made it under 2 years before multiple parts where the laces thread through had torn out. 

I was debating trying a third pair but after reading the reviews it seems my disappointment would only continue. So I'm leaning this review hoping the negative feedback will turn into a better boot again in the future. You guys value engineered too far.
review.name: Quality must be slipping...
comment: We are sorry to hear that you feel these boots did not perform as well as expected.  We appreciate you taking the time to leave us this review. We will pass along your feedback to our product development team!

review.reviewBody: I have been contemplating writing this email for quite some time but yesterday was the final straw. I have worn Vasque breeze hiking boots almost daily for the better part of 15 years probably in the neighborhood of 8 to 10 pairs. When I purchased the last pair about 6 months ago, I was shocked when I took them out of the box, I could tell right away that the quality of all material upper leather and soles was about half the thickness as my old pairs and everything about them is cheap except the price.  The path I normally walk has small rocks maybe 1-to-2-inch semi imbedded into the dirt. Walking on it with the new breeze boots actually becomes painful after a couple of miles due to how thin the soles are. I couldn't even imagine climbing up a rocky canyon or something of that nature in them. My house slippers have thicker soles on them than your new breeze designed soles. I wear my old pair when working in my shop they're still rugged thick upper, thick soles even being partially worn out and still comfortable just not much to look at and comparing them is like night and day compared to your new breeze hiking boots, honestly absolutely no comparison, I have spoken very highly to my friends over the years about your hiking boots but now I just tell them how disappointed I am that Vasque has gone the way of just about everybody else in the consumer market. Profit first consumer quality second. Thank you for the good years but I will never purchase another pair of your hiking boots again!
review.name: I could not be more disappointed
comment: Hi there, we are sorry to hear that these shoes are not working out for you. Please contact our customer service department at 800-733-9464 for further assistance. Thank you for this honest review!

review.reviewBody: I have been buying the breeze boot for about 20 years now. I would agree that the laces need to be a bit longer so you can double tie them. On  zappos web site they advertise that the 7742  has gore tex lining and vibram soles, you might want to check on that one. Other than that the boots are really comfortable.
review.name: nice fit and lightweight
comment: Thank you for the review! We appreciate your loyalty and support over the years!

name: Breeze Wide Hiking Boot - Men's

review.itemreviewed: Comfort Plus SI Sleeping Pad - Women's
review.reviewBody: [This review was collected as part of a promotion.] The Sea to Summit Women's sleeping pad has been great to sleep on overall. I did just get a warranty for a new one though in exchange for my less than one year former sleeping pad as it developed many tiny holes along the sides. When it is able to stay inflated, it is the most comfy sleeping pad I have ever used. I am a side sleeper and I have had a tough time finding a sleeping pad that is thick enough for my hips and shoulders and this one has been great. I am hoping the new one lasts longer.

review.itemreviewed: Comfort Plus SI Sleeping Pad - Women's
review.reviewBody: [This review was collected as part of a promotion.] Bought this after another company's pad failed after 5 nights use. I find the surface material pleasing to touch, the thickness is perfect and comfy. The width and length also comfy. I am a male, but bought this Women's pad since I am a side sleeper and the sizing meets my needs. Very happy!

review.itemreviewed: Comfort Plus SI Sleeping Pad - Women's
review.reviewBody: [This review was collected as part of a promotion.] This is great. It's the first time I've tried a self inflating pad. It is more comfortable than my current cushion sleeping pad, and it's shaped better (instead of a rectangle) so my arms or knees (side/3/4 side sleeper) stay on the pad and don't get cold at night. I used this in 20° weather, and along with my sleeping bag, I was warm and comfortable all night. Highly recommend.
review.name: Sleeping Pad

Great product, and great service.

review.itemreviewed: Comfort Plus SI Sleeping Pad - Women's
review.reviewBody:
I have been hunting for a warm and comfortable sleeping pad for a few months now and read tons of reviews. I was really excited about this mat because of the open cell foam, R value, and non slip features. It wasn't for me unfortunately, I returned it after one use but I'm glad to have tried it. I give it 3 stars because for a small person, I think it would be fine but for an average built person it's pretty small and confining, unless you sleep on your back the whole night through maybe...

What I did like:
-It had a nice, soft surface. If you use a quilt, this is lovely.
-Pillow lock is a nice bonus
-Easy to inflate (takes a little extra oomph the first inflation but it is compatible with the Ether Light pump sack) I promise it will puff up.
- Even though it's touted for car camping, I think it could be worth it to backpack with if you are not ultralight oriented.
- It did keep me (A quite cold sleeper) warm at about -5 Celsius. If you sleep cold and use it for deep winter, pair it with a 2nd mat.
-The valve is effective and easy to use to deflate it with the one way feature (just twist it so the bottom is out and when you roll it up, this prevents reinflation)
-If you are a good "roller" the stuff sack works for the size just fine, it's just a matter of keeping it tightly rolled from the get go.

What I didn't like:
- I am a bit of a tosser, turner and end up generally sleep on my front or side, and this pad was just too narrow and short for me (I'm 5'3" with an average build. A petite person might have better luck) Either my feet or head were a bit off the ends. When I tried sleeping on my back, my elbows hit the cold ground. It was just too small and I don't think I could have gotten used to it,
-The anti-slip features didn't keep my bag in place, I had to camp on a slight slope with it and trusted the anti slip to help, as it is marketed to do so.
- Even after deflating slightly for a bit of a softer sleep surface, I found it a little too firm (if you like a firmer surface you will probably like this better)
-As with any SI mat, you will probably have to double roll it to push all the air out (less of a dislike and more a reality with SI mats)

Overall, I think it is a good mat for a much smaller, quieter sleeper than myself. If you are restless and all over the place, then look for a rectangular mat, or consider the long/wide as this will be too confining.
review.name: Wanted to love this mat, some pros and some cons.

name: Comfort Plus SI Sleeping Pad - Women's

review.reviewBody:
What I got looks nothing like what's on the website.  I thought I was getting a black/dark (hence the name Black Scrib) Aero jersey with a full zipper.  Instead I got a white 1/2 zip jersey with light green and black accents.  The material and quality seem good, but it's not what I wanted.  It's also a large and for me at 5'9" 160, it runs too big, not form fitting.
I gave 2 stars because it looks nothing like what was offered for sale on the website.
review.name: not bad but nothing like what's pictured

review.reviewBody:
This really great jersey is made of a lightweight, breathable fabric that also appears to be durable. And the fit is great, because its pretty elastic and comfortable. I've ridden a few different brands of jersey, but keep coming back to pearl izumi. 

But for lightweight summer riding, all pearl izumi levels are not the same. The more entry level lines can be, relatively speaking, quite warm. The last few years my strategy has been finding the lighter weight Pro line on sale. Granted, its probably worth it to pay full price, but I'd rather get last year(s) line at discount.
review.name: Fantastic

review.reviewBody:
Really impressed with the overall feel of this jersey. I didn't expect such a light and breathable jersey to feel as robust as it does. 
A lot of summer weight and ultralight jerseys from a lot of "higher end" brands often times feel like they're days are numbered from the get go. One snag on a door handle or tree branch nd its over. 

That is not the case with this jersey at all! It's light, durable, and fits great! So in this situation, you get to pick all three, the cost is still a little steep but nothing is perfect!
review.name: Pearl but no one thinks its pearl

review.reviewBody: I work in hotel laundry & have to stock linen closets for three floors with closets at each end of the floors. I do a lot of walking & these shoes are amazingly supportive & comfortable. I’ve told several friends & family members how great these are!
review.name: I work in hotel laundry

review.reviewBody: I am not a fan of this much soul and would have returned the shoes if I could have figured out how to. Otherwise, the toebox was comfortably big enough for my bunions.
review.name: Too much soul for me

review.reviewBody: These arrived quickly. The curved sole provides for excellent support in the arch area and takes pressure off the heel and toe/metatarsal area. For me, this is an excellent feature due to my osteoarthritis. My foot is also narrow and this shoe fits me well. I’m looking forward to wearing these in my upcoming trips.
review.name: Good arch support

review.reviewBody: I bought these shoes in hopes to help with my plantar fasciitis. My doc recommended rocker bottom shoes, so I picked these out as I’ve had great luck with keen shoes in the past. These run very narrow in comparison to other keens I’ve purchased. No amount of lace loosening would have made these comfortable, so I returned them.
review.name: Too Narrow

review.reviewBody: I love the look of the style but unfortunately with a bad hip and shoulder they are nearly impossible to put on and tie . I wore them twice around the house and took them off because they made my feet hurt . The two times I wore them caused severe leg cramping that actually woke me from my sleep
review.name: To difficult to put on and tie

review.reviewBody: Great walking shoe for arthritic feet that need arch support and comfort. Rocking motion really helps to keep my hips aligned and shoulders back without much added effort
review.name: Comfortable and support

review.reviewBody: [This review was collected as part of a promotion.] Like walking on air. Easy to adjust to. Supports ankles. I wear 6.5. Size fit perfectly. Breathable and adds on a couple of inches to height, which is always nice.
review.name: Comfortable

hasVariant.description: Buy the Eureka! Canyon Footprint online or shop all Hike & Camp from Backcountry.com.

review.reviewBody: If you buy the tent, buy the footprint. They go together nicely.  You can’t have one without the other.
review.name: Can’t Have One Without the Other

review.reviewBody:
Great Company. Bought first tent an Equinox some 34 years ago. The 6 man is a replacement as the first one has seen its best days. Customer service with Johnson Camping is the best I have ever seen. Tent arrived on time but a few poles were damaged. New tent sent immediately with no questions asked. Great company and great product.
John Howard Jacksonville, Florida
review.name: Tent

review.reviewBody: The fitted Canyon footprint is the perfect companion for the Canyon/Jade tent.  Don’t buy one of these tents w/o a footprint!
review.name: Perfect companion to extent the life of your tent

review.reviewBody: Footprint is advertised as fitted for the Copper Canyon 6 tent but it’s too large. It definitely extends well beyond the 10’ x 10’ floor by at least 6”. We folded it as best we were able underneath the tent on all four sides. It then proceeded to rain for 48+ hours and on one side the water pooled very badly under the tent but above the ground cover. That’s because the ground cover became a “collector” of water and not the moisture/puncture barrier it’s supposed to be. That was discovered after taking the tent down after 108 hours of occupancy. So folks, it’s too big. Even the manual ‘shortening’ could not prevent water accumulation between the cover and the tent floor. Ground covers should be at least 12” shorter in all 4 dimensions of the tent footprint to prevent water collection. All serious tenters know this. The tent was a first class champion and nothing seeped through. Dry as a bone after 60 hours of serious direct water exposure. The ground cover could be repurposed to a cover for the fly when under trees, because it’s got extremely useful and strong tie outs sewn at all four corners!! Eureka, please figure out and correct the ground cover sizing; Thank you for listening
review.name: LX6 Ground Cover too Large
comment: Thank you for your review of the 6P Canyon Fitted Footprint. This footprint measures 114 in. (9 1/2 ft.) square and is the largest of our Fitted Footprints. Please double-check that your tent is NOT the smaller Copper Canyon 4P model. At 96 inches, this larger footprint WILL protrude appx. 9 inches on every side. If you feel there is a flaw in the Fitted Footprint, please contact our Customer Service deparment toll-free at 1-800-572-8822 Mon-Fri between 8 a.m. and 4:30 p.m. and we will be happy to assist you with replacement options.

review.reviewBody: This perfectly fit beneath my 4 person tent.  Great!
review.name: Perfect Fit

review.reviewBody: The size of the Jade Canyon 6 P tent is listed as 10'x10'.  The size of the footprint is listed as 9.5' x 9.5'.  I set it up this weekend, but the footprint seemed too large, in that it extended from the bottom of the tent.  It rained a lot and water got between the floor bottom and the foot print.  The inside of the floor did not get wet.  It was difficult for me to arrange the foot print so it did not extend beyond the floor.  I thought I had the tent staked out properly.  What did I do wrong?  I was thinking next time to fold and tape the edges to make a smaller area to prevent water from getting between the floor and the footprint.  Any other suggestions?
review.name: 6 P canyon Fitted footpring

review.reviewBody: I was happy with the adjustable cords on the corners. Nice material. Hope to use it with our Jade Canyon 6 for as long as we had our Equinox 6      27 Years
review.name: Good Quality

review.reviewBody: I set up the tent right after I bought it to seal the seams as directed.  This took several hours.  One of the main tent poles elastic cord broke when I took it down.  I wrote to Eureka and did not receive a response.  The neon yellow exclamation point is hideous!  The rest seems nice.
review.name: Pole cord broke on 1st use
comment: Thank you for taking the time to reach about about your concern. I sincerely apologize for our delay in response. If this has not yet been taken care of, please contact us at your convenience, 1-800-572-8822 8am-5pm EST Monday-Friday as we want you to be able to enjoy your purchase.

review.reviewBody: This ground cloth is listed to fit the Eureka 4 person Copper Canyon tent, and it certainly does. The added corner straps work well with the tent stakes as well. Cleans up easily. I didn't hit rain with this yet, but I'm quite sure it will repel ground water 100% as it is vinyl/plastic.
review.name: Completes the Tent

review.reviewBody: I bought this Fitted Footprint to protect it from any potential punctures, and to help keep the bottom floor of my tent clean. It fits my Eureka Jade Canyon 6 Person Tent perfectly. I highly recommend purchasing this item.
review.name: Jade Canyon 6P Tent Fitted Footprint

name: Canyon Footprint

review.itemreviewed: Taiss Light Mid GTX Mountaineering Boot - Men's
review.reviewBody: These run VERY small and very narrow. I order 1.5 sizes up and that was still insufficient to avoid losing toenails on a climb. They are however, great for warmer condition climbs being lightweight and not super insulated (they were plenty warm at 0C).
review.name: Narrow and stiff

review.itemreviewed: Taiss Light Mid GTX Mountaineering Boot - Men's
review.reviewBody:
I hiked the entire wonderland trail (100miles over 7 days) early season in these bad boys. Didn’t get a single hot spot, blister, foot pain, etc even with consecutive days of water crossings/soggy socks/snow travel. Don’t remember there being any break in period either when I first got them. They were comfortable right out the gate.

I am a woman with wider feet and heard these boots are on the narrower side, so I opted to buy the men’s version, and sized up. These boots are awesome, highly recommend!!
review.name: Incredibly lightweight and comfortable

review.itemreviewed: Taiss Light Mid GTX Mountaineering Boot - Men's
review.reviewBody: Stiff boot, low to the ground, heel is lower than most other mountaineering boots, weighs ~26oz size 47. I like all these features. For walking approach trails, it's not ideal due to the stiffness but that may break in over time. I think that adding an easier flex area at the forefoot would help, while still maintaining a still sole otherwise but that would make crampons less comfortable. The tongue could have fabric all the way up both sides to male the waterproofing go up higher for certain. The fit is very snug, socklike, and luckily the boot very closely conforms to my foot shape. My toes are all very nearly touching the front of the boot, but the laces lock well at the ankle lace locks. The asymmetrical toe lacing system is almost unneeded because the sock fit is so snug all the way forward--I worry that there is not enough room for thicker socks and in cold weather you may feel it. I would love something like this with a Stiff sole but with forefoot flex in a shoe version. The outer edge of the bottom of the sole is almost under the outer edge of my foot--making edging and sidehilling nice but feels like the ankle wants to roll sideways on flatter ground. I think the low stiff sole makes up for this and it is stable walking. Going downhill I started to get a little knee pain, probably due to the sole being stiffer and not broken in,  little cushioning, and a flatter heel to toe drop, but may improve with time. Have worn it in 90+ degrees desert cliff/canyon hiking, with 40 lbs and my feet weren't soaked. (Paired with thin socks)
review.name: Stiff, low to ground

review.itemreviewed: Taiss Light Mid GTX Mountaineering Boot - Men's
review.reviewBody:
Most of my time in the mountains is on skis or rock, but I needed a general purpose, lightweight mountain boot for use on snow or easy rock, and I'm confident I've found it with this boot. They are impressively light on the feet, required very little break in before all-day comfort, and keep my feet dry in slushy snow conditions. 

They have enough insulation to provide some cushion for kicking steps, but they are not a warm boot, so they may not be an appropriate choice for those with cold feet looking for a 4-season boot, but as a spring/summer boot or for those with hot feet who prefer a light and fast approach to the mountains, this boot is an excellent choice.
review.name: So light and easy break in

review.itemreviewed: Taiss Light Mid GTX Mountaineering Boot - Men's
review.reviewBody: very comfortable and warm. bought them for mountaineering in Antarctica and they were perfect.
review.name: solid boots

review.itemreviewed: Taiss Light Mid GTX Mountaineering Boot - Men's
review.reviewBody: Very comfortable for long hikes, feet stay dry, and durable.

review.itemreviewed: Taiss Light Mid GTX Mountaineering Boot - Men's
review.reviewBody: Great boot! Fits small in this production. Light and stiff.

review.itemreviewed: Taiss Light Mid GTX Mountaineering Boot - Men's
review.reviewBody: I have used and abused Taiss boots in many situations. These are ideal for backpacking and provide excellent support and comfort. I use the boots for 4 season hiking in the Canadian Rockies. They have always kept me warm and dry. I've been wearing Mammut hiking boots for over twenty years and thousands of miles of trails so these aren't my first pair of Taiss and probably won't be my last. The soles and toe caps aren't sturdy enough for dedicated scrambling but can hold up to bagging a summit or two when backpacking in Banff and Jasper
review.name: My go-to boots

review.itemreviewed: Taiss Light Mid GTX Mountaineering Boot - Men's
review.reviewBody:
I was looking for a lightweight boot that can be used all four seasons for rock, snow and icy terrain. The Taiss fits this bill perfectly. 

The boot is extremely light, I barely feel I have anything on my feet. Despite being light, it is also very stiff: there's minimal amount of flex in the forefoot that makes walking comfortable on flat terrain. The boot climbs well on rock: can fit into cracks and hold steady. The sole has enough grip on wet and muddy terrain, for everything else it takes microspikes or hybrid crampons easily. 

In terms of fit: I sized up a whole size vs my street shoes. Having worn it multiple times it barely required any break-in for me. There's very little heel and toe movement - I did not have any issues with toes hitting the front of the boot on steep downhill climbs. I like how the toe area is firm and sturdy and able to take lots of abuse. I've waded through small streams and the boot was waterproof probably up to about 4 inches. It is also quite warm and I had no cold spots while being out on snow and ice in negative 5-10 C temperatures (wearing thick mountaineering socks). 

My only slight criticism is the lacing system: the gusseted tongue slips under the cuff on the outside of the ankle and often needs to be adjusted to make a tight fit as the laces became somewhat loose, compromising ankle hold and water resistance. The factory laces seem to be a bit too thin for me and I am considering replacing them with sturdier ones at some point. 

Overall, I highly recommend this if you need a stiff, super lightweight boot that can be used on varied terrain and serves well as an approach shoe too.
review.name: Extremely light and precise boot

review.itemreviewed: Taiss Light Mid GTX Mountaineering Boot - Men's
review.reviewBody: Very lightweight boot with crampon compatibility and excellent stiffness. Vibram soles provide good traction on rock slabs and scrambles. Excellent toe design instills confidence on alpine climbs. I usually wear an 11.5 but sized up to a 12.5 and they fit well.
review.name: Lightweight Mountain Boots

name: Taiss Light Mid GTX Mountaineering Boot - Men's

review.reviewBody: These shoes are not only cute but comfortable and waterproof!

review.reviewBody: Love them! So comfy and stylish. I got tons of compliments’

description: Buy the Armada Declivity 92 Ti Ski - 2024 online or shop all Ski from Backcountry.com.

hasVariant.name: Declivity 92 Ti Ski - 2024
hasVariant.description: Buy the Armada Declivity 92 Ti Ski - 2024 online or shop all Ski from Backcountry.com.

review.reviewBody: OMG! these skis are great everywhere. If you want 1 ski to take on a trip and you're unsure of the conditions, this is it. They're good up to 15cm powder and great on hard pack. For icy conditions or more than 15cm powder you will probably want something else. They're a beauty combination of light weight and dampness. I'll take a damp ski over light ones. That's why I've moved away from some atomic skis They're very light but pingy and don't feel great when the snow is chunky or rough.  These are lighter than my enforcer 88 and better in deeper snow, but not quite as damp. Also you don't have to get them up to top speed to feel fun - a good ski for intermediate through expert. If you like skiing outside of the park,  you NEED to get on a pair of the declivity 82 or 92.
review.name: Excellent high performance all mountain ski.

review.reviewBody: These skis do great in soft chop, hard pack, 15 cm powder, high speed 85kmh. These skis do it all all over the hill. They really are a do it all ski.
review.name: Amazing truly all mountain ski

name: Declivity 92 Ti Ski - 2024

hasVariant.name: Sprinter 500 Headlamp

hasVariant.name: Sprinter 500 Headlamp
hasVariant.description: Buy the Black Diamond Sprinter 500 Headlamp online or shop all Hike & Camp from Backcountry.com.

review.reviewBody: Light enough on the head, you don’t feel it. Great for winter running, especially with the red backlight!
review.name: Great headtorch

review.reviewBody: Lightweight, long battery life, and fits comfortably on the head without shaking or sliding as you run. Would recommend for any early morning or late night runner who wants to have better visibility.
review.name: Perfect for Runners

review.reviewBody: Best headlamp I've ever used for running. Love the stormproofing, rear light, and vertical strap.
review.name: Best headlamp I've ever used

review.reviewBody: Only reason I'm giving 4/5 is because its rather difficult to have this sit on your head correctly with a pony tail / as someone with a lot of hair. Either I put my pony tail off centre, feeling rather uncomfortable and from what others have told me, my hair covers the back light. Otherwise, great visibility.
review.name: Great for most part

review.reviewBody: The headlight functions perfectly. Back flasher mode gives plenty of warning to approaching cars and the front light is plenty bright.
review.name: Sprinter 500 Headlight

review.reviewBody: I had an older version and was saddened when it broke. Tried a Nebo rechargable and it was subpar. so, i broke down and got this and the battery has lasted for several days now. i love the red blinkers on the back and how adjustable it is. overall it is quite adjustable and fits over my hat and works like a headlamp should. the downsides are that it takes microusb (come on usb c should be standard for everything!) and i wish the front light had a red light like my original, but having a decent rechargeable battery makes it worth it.
review.name: black diamond headlamp

review.reviewBody: I recently purchased this headlamp for trail running, mostly shorter, runs in the dark, no more than 90 minutes. I like how you can set the front and back lighting systems independently, and I find the front light grand seen a lot of control. The weight and comfort are good, not as excellent as a lighter weight headlamp that I had that broke, and I think that weight versus durability may be a necessary trade-off. Yes, I would purchase this again.
review.name: Meets Expectations - Happy with purchase

review.reviewBody: This new Sprinter 500 is excellent. I had used an earlier model (pre-Sprinter 275) for 5 years. It was still working, but the headstrap was shot and a replacement was no longer available. The 500 is bright and shines far ahead when I need that, but is still bright enough when there is a bit of ambient light and I reduce the brightness. I look forward to many years of running with this headlamp.
review.name: I Can See!!

review.reviewBody: I love my Black diamond Spot 400, but I upgraded to the Sprinter 500 headlamp to power through the night when I am running 100M Ultras. Initially, I was worried that the Sprinter 500 would be too bulky, but the design is actually quite comfortable.
review.name: Light up the overnight Ultras

review.reviewBody: Not as bright as I was hoping for. Trail running in the forest at night is doable with this headlamp but not ideal. Not great vis in foggy/misty conditions due to only the single flood light setting. Love the simplified controls, very comfortable also.
review.name: Simple and effective

name: Sprinter 500 Headlamp

review.itemreviewed: Skipper II Strawberries Rain Boot - Toddler Girls'
review.reviewBody: We just received these boots yesterday. As soon as my daughter put them on she slipped twice which is completely odd for rain boots. They came with some kind of oil on the bottoms, I guess to prevent them from cracking but I think customers should be warned. I wanted to return but she really wanted them, once we walked on the side walk the grip was great. I WOULD NOT RECOMMEND FOR BABIES OR TODDLERS LEARNING TO WALK. review.reviewBody: Used this on a recent fishing trip as my day hiking bag. Great bag! Lightweight, versatile and very comfortable.
review.name: Excellent day hiking pack!

review.reviewBody: Bought as a large day/summit pack, turns out to be perfect and a light overnight bag in the high Mtn’s. Used it to link up four fourteeners last week.
review.name: Lite and roomy

review.reviewBody: The only thing I would change is I would probably put a pocket underneath the lid but other than that best travel pack I’ve ever had
review.name: Good pack

review.reviewBody: London, France, Italy, Switzerland, Austria, Costa Rica. Best pack ever made.  Super light weight.  Just enough padding without overdoing it. My sunburned shoulders appreciated it. Compartments perfect size to hold passports and small wallets. Side pouch holds large water bottle and you can sinch it tighter for smaller bottle's. Clips were there should be. Zippers are great quality. Material dries fast. Washes great. Worth every single penny. We also traveled with a similar size Patagonia.. can’t even compare the two. This backpack is a million times better.
review.name: Best travel pack

review.reviewBody: I've been wanting a Mystery Ranch pack for years & I was so excited to try this cool self-stuffing day pack.  The quality is great, but the sternum strap is located too high for my frame (6' male 190 lbs) and it rubs against my lower neck, which is quite uncomfortable when hiking.  Additionally, I'm not a fan of the water port only being located on the left.  I ended up giving the pack to my wife who likes it okay.  I wanted to like this pack so bad :(
review.name: Uncomfortable sternum strap

review.reviewBody: This is NOT a packable backpack. By that I mean it is too big to be considered that. This is actually good, very good in fact. The quality of materials and construction make it a bit big.Also returning it to it's "pack" would be difficult and eventually probably would damage the pack. It looks great, well thought out and constructed. The size seems just right and the shoulder straps should be fine. I plan to leave it flat in my travel stuff or just stuff it.
review.name: Very happy

review.reviewBody: Bought the In and Out 22 during the Black Friday Sale, happened to receive a link to it in an email, I have no idea where it is on the site. They definitely need to market this one more. I'm so glad I got that email because this bag checks a lot of boxes for me that other bags don't. First off, it's the most packable bag I've ever owned, it stuffs into its own pocket when space is at a premium. But because of that, there is no padding, support, or frame, which for me is okay for shorter hikes or walks around town with the kids. I've carried groceries home in it, so it's already saved me 10 cents! It's the only grocery bag I can actually remember... Also did a 5 mile hike in it carrying a nalgene, headlamp, gloves, extra layers, bag of gorp, stuff for the dog, and had room to spare. I had to place items intentionally for that long since, again, there is no padding or support, but it did great. Will also be my concert bag now since it is primarily just the one big opening. I think it will also be my summit bag but need to get more miles on it first. Love the water bottle pocket on the side and the front shove it pocket, I think those pockets should be mandatory on all bags. Also loaded with cinch straps and daisy chains for more hauling capability. I suppose my only complaint is the buckles for the top lid are very small and kind of hard to open with gloves on, but I understand why they are that size for packability. Also won't be using it to commute with laptop/tablet as there is no padding. Like I said, this bag is great for what it is, and I'm excited to find more excuses to use it.
review.name: Great for what it is!

review.reviewBody: Great versatile pack.  Good for just about any quick excursion.
review.name: Amazing pack

review.reviewBody: Many of the adventure trips that I lead entail a 12-15 mile hike to a pack drop. I got the IN and OUT 22 for this purpose, and it worked perfectly. Very sturdy day pack and spacious for all the gear that I need for a long day getting 8 to 10 people up the mountain. The way it packs down into its external pocket enables me to put it in my backpack for the rest of the trip, as well as take it out for summits and day hikes to alpine lakes. This is the best day pack that I have ever had. I highly recommend it to all my participants.
review.name: Perfect Day Pack

review.reviewBody: I bought this bag to take to Europe and it did a great job. The bag is nice and light and I love how it packs away in it's own front pocket. I wish the clips that keep the top flap down were bigger but I understand that would ad weight and bulk. The front pocket is just big enough to hold a thin paper back book and not much else. Another nit-picky point is my empty Smartwater bottle gets pushed up and wants to fall out of the side pocket.
review.name: Nice and light

name: In & Out 22L Backpack

review.reviewBody:
[This review was collected as part of a promotion.] Bought these to replace some standard pegs that weren't sturdy enough to hammer into rocky ground. 
I really love the tri-point design and the addition of reflective pull cords!! Such a great idea!
review.name: Bought these to replace some

review.reviewBody: [This review was collected as part of a promotion.] Great stakes for securing my tent in heavy weather. Easy to place and remove, but don't get pulled out by wind.
review.name: A Stake in a good night sleep

review.reviewBody: Did halfway so far with them on the PCT. Best Stake design i found so far similar light weight like all the others and super durable. Awesome product always want to have those.
review.name: Great stakes

review.reviewBody: These tent pegs have a great design. This allows me to beat on them with my plastic tent peg hammer without damage. They are very light weight and durable. I am a long-distance bicyclist and these pack very nicely. Thanks again for a great product.
review.name: These tent pegs have a

review.reviewBody: Love these tent stakes. Best we have ever owned. Visible, nice size and sturdy. Loop to pull out of ground but still light weight.
review.name: Best tent stakes

review.reviewBody: Bought a set to supplement the factory pegs on my four person, standing height tent and they are well worth it. They didn't budge at all during a windy thunder storm even when stuck in loose soil. These pegs have been the best that I've used for sandy and loose soil conditions, the flat surface areas hold way better than the usual round pegs that come with most tents. Three different notches for the guy lines also offer a better pull angle if the peg won't sink to full depth because of rocks or roots, and the pull loop makes pulling them out really easy. Someone who actually uses tents designed these pegs. Am definitely getting another set to go with my smaller backpacking tent.
review.name: Great tent pegs!

review.reviewBody: Very handy & sturdy pegs, especially with the nice- glow loops!
review.name: Nice addition to my setup gear

review.reviewBody:
These were one of two new types of stake that I recently bought after years of using (and often fighting with) titanium shepherd's hooks. Grew tired of the latter just not going into decomposed granite (DG), their bending woefully at the effort, and the resulting need to deadman way too often.

The main stakes I chose to replace those are titanium nails. But I also added these S2S Ground Control stakes. Brought 6 nails (the minimum for my tent) and 2 of these S2S stakes on recent trips. This is a much heavier kit overall than my shepherd's hook setup. But they've definitely proved worth it.

The S2S pegs, particular, worked great. And were surprisingly adept (given their wide cross-section) at banging into DG. When they couldn't go all the way down, of course they have the multiple hooks so that you can still get a good lock on the line. And they do seem like they'd work for laying sideways as a (shiver at the thought) deadman anchor.

Maybe you could remove one star here for the weight. But that doesn't seem fair. You know going into it that these are not the whisper-lightest pegs you can buy. They're not really that heavy for the performance (takes a pounding, multiple hooks, deadman anchor) that they give you.

Really well made. Burly. Highly visible. They'll be staying in my kit. Another fine S2S product.
review.name: Great option

review.reviewBody: Great design that holds in many types of soil and rigging situations, lite weight, and easy to pack.
review.name: Great design that holds in

review.reviewBody: Smart design, rugged, and a best-in-class pull-loop..
review.name: Solid Stakes..

review.itemreviewed: Descendant Carbon Eagle DUB Crankset - Boost
review.reviewBody: Great Crankset! They have been an excellent upgrade for my bike.
review.name: Excellent performance at a great price

review.itemreviewed: Descendant Carbon Eagle DUB Crankset - Boost
review.reviewBody: These replaced GX alloy cranks.  The ride improvement was noticeable.  If you want the great performance of a carbon crank without spending a ton this is the one.  Graphics are low key in a good way, the cranks are very good looking.  They deliver the stiffness to improve power transfer into the drivetrain, I agree with another reviewer that they have some damping qualities as well.  If you are a smaller rider you might not notice the difference between alloy and carbon but for those on the larger side when you get out of saddle and crank the difference is obvious.  I will buy these again for a hard tail build I am working on.
review.name: Low key graphics and great performance

review.itemreviewed: Descendant Carbon Eagle DUB Crankset - Boost
review.reviewBody: Carbon Descendant crank that's uber-stiff and really does help mute the chatter through your feet and keep them planted. I'm a 32" inseam on a large v3 Bronson and moving to 170mm has helped me spin a higher cadence while climbing. Already have the DUB system, so these with some crank boots was all I needed. Could not be more pleased with this crankset
review.name: Durable, light enough, chatter dampening

review.itemreviewed: Descendant Carbon Eagle DUB Crankset - Boost
review.reviewBody:
Very happy with this crankset.  Upgraded from a GX aluminum crankset but didn't want to drop over $400 for a carbon crank.  This isn't the lightest crankset, like the XX1 or XO1, but it's not that far off.  Going from an aluminum GX crankset with GXP BB to this crankset with the new DUB BB, the weight savings was exactly 100g.  (oh and I moved from 175mm to 170mm crank arms at the same time)  
This crankset looks fantastic, but aesthetics aside, the most noticeable thing for me what the stiffness.  It's notably more stiff while pedaling and especially under hard efforts out of the saddle, like downhill sprints.  It feels like all of my effort is translated into forward momentum with very little flex.  I can't say if this is because of the carbon layup, or perhaps it's the DUB spindle, I don't know.  My old GX cranks was a smaller diameter GXP BB version.  The bearing pre-load that they put on these is also really great.  Simple concept to dial in just the right amount of tension on the bearings for butter smooth operation with zero play.  
Do note that if you aren't already running a DUB bottom bracket, you will need to get one.  They don't cost much and the BB weighed substantially less than my GXP BB.  Also note that if you are using a threaded BSA style BB, you will need a different 12-tooth BB tool for the DUB bottom bracket.  It's NOT the same tool as the GXP or shimano BB.   If you are thinking about a new crankset, throw down.  This thing rocks.  Oh, and don't forget the crank boots for the ends.
review.name: Crazy stiff, well priced, looks awesome

name: Descendant Carbon Eagle DUB Crankset - Boost
